--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "David" <achepati67@y...> wrote:
> >Dear Members,
> >
> >I whould like to test a class with a main(String[] args) method.
Depending
> >on the input argument it executes one thing or the other. The
problem is
> >that on my main(String[] args) method at the end or when it founds
an
> error,
> >the method System.exit() is invoked. So when I define jUnit test
cases
> >(methods with prefix test), jUnits only runs the first test,
because
> some>System.exit() was invoked.
> >Is there any way to test such kind of situations?
> >Thanks in advance,
>
> The solution propoused by Bern was:
>
> java.lang.System is final and does not implement interfaces,so
there is no
> chance to replace ist behaviour.You may want to replace calls to
> System.exit() with calls againstan interface you define. Under test
use an
> implementation which allowsyourtest code to chech if the exit
method has
> been called by main() but whichdoes not exit the VM. In production
use an
> implememtation which delegatesto System.exit().
>
> As far as I know what you mean could be implemented like this: (see
comments
> below)
>
> package com.my.example
>
> public class Example {
> static Finish _finish = new Example.ProductionFinish();//
private package
> (static because it is
>
// going to be used on main.)
> static void setFinish(Finish value){_finish = value;} //
private package
>
> static main (String[] args)
>
> boolean goOn = true; // because we don't exit on
testing mode,
> // we need a way for
controling the execution flow.
> if (someCondition) {// first checking (exceptional
flow)
> goOn = finish.do(-1);
> }
> // ... put other checking here
> if (goOn && otherCondition) {// main flow
> finish.do(0);
> }
> }
>
> /* Now we define the interface Finish and its default
implementation (as
> inner classes
> with private-package visibility, because we have to define
ONLY for testing
> purpose this
> interface!)*/
>
> interface Finish {
> boolean do(int i);
> }
>
> class ProductionFinish {// its default implementation (used
on production
> mode)
> ProductionFinish(){} // default constructor with
private-package
> visibility
> boolean do(int i) {
> System.exit(i);
> }
> }
> }
>
> Now on the testing class defined on the same package:
>
> package com.my.example
>
> public class ExampleTest extends TestCase{
> // ...
> protected void setUp (){Example.setFinish(new
> ExampleTest.TestingFinish());}
> }
> class TestingFinish implements Example.Finish{
> TestingFinish (){} // default constructor with
private-package visibility
> boolean do(int i) { // We have to stop on every case!
> return false;
> }
> }
> }
>
> COMMENTS:
>
> - About this suggestion and the corresponding implementation,
because we
> need a default implementation ALWAYS (for production), then instead
of using
> an INTERFACE, it is BETTER to just define the class Finish as
ABSTRACT (the
> do(int i) method should be abstract)
>
> - You have to write A LOT for makeing a very simple task. I have
implemented
> a simpler solution, just do the following steps:
>
> a) Define on the class to test (Example), the static boolean field
_TEST as
> private-package. This field is initialized with default value: false
> (production)
>
> b) Define a STATIC PRIVATE method finish, like this:
> private static boolean finish(int i) {
> if(!_TEST) {
> System.exit(i);
> }
> return false;
> }
> c) On the testing class (ExampleTest), set on the setup() method,
the field
> _TEST to true.
>
>
> Now we have:
>
> package com.my.example
>
> public class Example {
> static boolean _TEST = false;
>
> static main (String[] args)
>
> boolean goOn = true;
> if (someCondition) {// fist checking
> goOn = finish(-1);
> }
> // ... put other checking here
> if (goOn && otherCondition) {// the last condition
(end of the program)
> finish(-1);
> }
> }
>
> private static boolean finish (int i) {
> if (!_TEST) {
> System.exit(i);
> }
> return false;
> }
> }
>
> package com.my.example
>
> public class ExampleTest extends TestCase{
> // ...
> protected void setUp (){Example._TEST = true;}
> }
> }
>
> I think this solution is enough. Any suggestion?
>
> Thanks in advance,
>
> David


Just wondering how the testMain() looks like? How do you cover for
all different arguments combination? Do you have to separate testMain
() for each scenario? Thanks!
[David Leal] In general I have the following test methods:
testMain_help for testing when the user invokes the "-h". "-help" on my
case.
testMain_exceptionalFlow for testing situation that produces errors and
the process is abruptly stoped.
testMain_mainFlow it is the main flow execution.

I coollects all possible outputs: error and standard output on files
(using the methods: System.setOut(), System.setErr()) and then compare the
files with the expected ones. That is may test.

That is my aproach, because on test mode the main() method doesn't finish
(Example._TEST= true), we can test more than one invocation to the method.

Hope this help,

David
